best_examples.answer: Fin designs that have three or four triangular fins that are at the base end of the rocket work best. They stabilise the rocket and make it more aerodynamic or streamlined
best_examples.rubric: {"criteria": "Decide which variables should be changed, measured and controlled in fair tests and accurately observe, measure and record data", "total_score": 2, "items": ["I can explain my response", "I can identify which fin design worked best", "No evidence"]}
best_examples.question: Which fin design worked best? Why?

best_examples.answer: The Earth’s orbit around the Sun is an elliptical or oval shape. This means that the Earth is sometimes closer to the Sun than at other times
best_examples.rubric: {"criteria": "Earth is part of a system of planets orbiting around a star (the Sun)", "total_score": 2, "items": ["I can explain the shape of the Earth's orbit", "I can describe the shape of the Earth's orbit", "No evidence"]}
best_examples.question: Describe the shape of the Earth’s orbit around the Sun

best_examples.answer: They need to make sure that the quantity of fuel will produce the strongest reaction, which will give the rocket the biggest thrust as it takes off. They also need to be precise with fuel measurements because they can't carry extra fuel - the extra weight would weigh the rocket down and impair its ability to exit the atmosphere
best_examples.rubric: {"criteria": "Scientific knowledge is used to solve problems and inform personal and community decisions\n", "total_score": 2, "items": ["I can explain two reasons why scientists need to be precise with their fuel calculations", "I can explain one reason why scientists need to be precise with their fuel calculations", "No evidence"]}
best_examples.question: Why do you think the NASA scientists need to be very precise with the amount of fuel they have on board the rocket before take-off?
